title: As of 1 November 2016, how much money will the Center for Responsive Politics report that Donald Trump's campaign committee and outside groups have spent on his campaign?
possible_answers: More than $500 million but less than $750 million
preds:
Total spent to date according to Bloomberg $429.5M
Tracking the 2016 Presidential Money Race
http://www.bloomberg.com/politics/graphics/2016-presidential-campaign-fundraising/ Trump has claimed he will spend an additional $100 million, which makes the 500-750 million bucket the safest.

Here's the latest: Several news sources reported yesterday that Trump had just wired $10M into his campaign. 
The Clinton camp said Trump was planning to spend $25M on tv ads for the final stretch.  Open Secrets data was updated to reflect Oct. 19 FEC report but the new numbers don't make sense when compared to what the site listed as of Sept 30.  (big discrepancy of some $80M on amount spent). Comparing their new data with FEC reports and other sources.  Here's what Open Secrets has as of now:  TOTAL RAISED:
Trump:  $247,541,449 / Outside groups supporting Trump:  $59,389,531	
Total for both: $306,930,980 TOTAL SPENT:
Trump:	$231,546,996  /  Outside groups supporting Trump:	$54,023,785	
Total for both:  $285,570,781 CASH ON HAND: 
Trump: $15,994,454	/  Outside groups: $5,365,745	/  Total:  $21,360,199
Debts	$2,086,572	 Link to the actual FEC FILING summary for Trump: 
http://www.fec.gov/fecviewer/CandidateCommitteeDetail.do?tabIndex=1&candidateCommitteeId=P80001571 Link to CENTER FOR PUBLIC INTEGRITY numbers:
$282 Million SPENT by the Trump campaign, latest update October 21. 
https://www.publicintegrity.org/2015/10/16/18631/see-how-much-2016-presidential-candidates-have-raised-so-far Pretty clear picture here for 100% prob. total will be between $250M-$500M.

http://www.opensecrets.org/pres16/candidate.php?id=N00023864 What the heck? Overnight, in the last 12 hours,  the numbers have changed AGAIN!
What is weird about this is that the "as of" dates have not changed. The website NOW shows 
as of 10/19 DT campaign spent $231,546,996 
as of 10/21 outside groups spent $54,023,785 
for a total spent of $285,570,781 I do not trust this website's data.

Good spotting from @Anneinak
That's the third time the figures have changed unexpectedly and in a big way.
Raising 85% to 96%.

http://www.opensecrets.org/pres16/candidate.php?id=N00023864 What the heck?  In the last 9 hours the numbers have changed dramatically DOWNWARDS by $135,887,147! The website now shows 
as of 10/19  DT campaign spent     $231,546,996
as of 10/21  outside groups spent   $47,537,084
for a total spent of                           $279,084,080

In interview with Bret Baier of Fox News, Trump promised to put $10M into his campaign (he also sent an email saying this).  Didn't specify if it was cash or in-kind (plane, office space etc).  That's significantly less than expected (he had told George Stephanopoulos that he expected to contribute $100M. So far, he has given $56M).  http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/donald-trump-plans-spend-campaign-final-weeks/story?id=43076291 Also reported this week that, on Oct 1, Trump had pledged to triple donations for 24 hours (donors gave $165,829 but Trump only gave $30,682)  He still has time to catch up but with 11 days to go, is not looking like it.  As a business man, his instincts may advise him against additional spending if there is no clear path to 270.  And for the purpose of this question, we're looking at Nov 1 numbers... It's possible that with Hillary's new email investigation (Comey's letter to congressional committees regarding emails found on Anthony Weiner's devices), if evidence of criminality is found, Trump's camp may see a clear path to winning and decide to make a bigger infusion of cash in the final days.  That's still a big if.
As of October 21st it is $414,971,227. They don't plan any fundraisers, even if all the cash is spent now, it will be impossible to cross the $500 m barrier.

http://www.opensecrets.org/pres16/candidate.php?id=N00023864 Combined total spent  (campaign as of 10/19 & outside sources as of 10/21 )   $414,971,227  
Combined  Cash on Hand	                                                                                             $47,066,737 If they spent every penny they have it would amount to                                          $462,037,964
but that number is not relevant.  The only thing that matters for the purpose of this question is what is showing on this site on as the combined total spent, which currently is $414,971,227

Correcting a forecasting error as pointed out by @Clinton These are Trump's fundraising numbers as of September 30: Campaign committee:  $218,763,241	
Outside groups: $214,496,514
Combined: $433,259,755 Once the October numbers are added, the Trump campaign should be very close to or pass the $500M mark.   As per NPR News on Oct. 26, Trump has said he will contribute $100M in total to his campaign.  NPR reported he has already given $56M (that includes the $50M he spent in the primaries when he said he was funding his campaign and didn't need donations). We can assume then that he will be giving another $50M in the final stretch.  
As of last week, the Trump campaign said it was stopping high-dollar fundraising events (the proceeds of which benefit other Republican candidates). They said they were pulling in enough money from online fundraising. (In contrast, Hillary Clinton has at least 41 fundraisers scheduled before Election Day.) http://billmoyers.com/story/mr-10-26-16-trump-cuts-off-gop-roger-stone-vote-protectors/ Total amounts in hand at the end of September:  
Trump campaign: $34,776,288 
Outside groups had:	$31,072,283	
Total:  $65,848,571 On another note, the Trump campaign had purchased millions worth of TV ads in several states for mid October but then cancelled them. The campaign said the money was just being spent in other more competitive states.  These are the amounts spent as of September 30:
Campaign Committee: $183,986,953	$
Outside Groups:  $183,424,231	
Total amount spent:  $367,411,184 Many have criticized Trump for running the campaign on the cheap.  Looking at the amount he has spent, he might fall short the $500M mark given his current spending trends.  There are reports of offices opening in states like Florida and Pennsylvania just to close a few weeks later or not be in operation. Also reports of campaign asking for yard signs and other promotional items from campaign (as per campaign in Nevada) and not receiving any response from the Trump camp.   Trump is said to have spent $70M in September (he had only spent $30M in August).  October and the first week in November just before the election might see an increase but it would have to be over $133M to be above the $500M mark.   Taking a look at campaign expenses, Trump spent "at least $1 million on his own aircraft and Trump-owned hotels, resorts or office buildings. In addition to the $21 million he spent on online advertising — his single largest expense — he was billed at least $5 million by Cambridge Analytica, a publicity-shy data mining and analytics firm owned by Trumpf’s chief financial benefactor, the wealthy investor Robert Mercer."   http://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/21/us/politics/campaign-fundraising-money.html?_r=0 Given that Trump's GOTV operation is not the standard for presidential campaigns, his expenses in October will not be as high on that front.  Same goes for data as he spent $5M in September.  Most of the money will most likely go into tv advertising.  The GOP was said to be holding back on mailers, another big expense.

These are Trump's numbers as of September 30: Campaign committee:  $218,763,241	
Outside groups: $214,496,514
Combined: $433,259,755 Once the October numbers are added, the Trump campaign should be very close to or pass the $500M mark.   Heard on NPR today that Trump is expecting to contribute $100M in total to his campaign.  NPR reported he has already given $56M (that includes the $50M he spent in the primaries when he said he was funding his campaign and didn't need donations). We can assume then that he will be giving another $50M in the final stretch.  
As of last week, the Trump campaign said it was stopping high-dollar fundraising events (the proceeds of which benefit other Republican candidates). They said they were pulling in enough money from online fundraising. (In contrast, Hillary Clinton has at least 41 fundraisers scheduled before Election Day.) http://billmoyers.com/story/mr-10-26-16-trump-cuts-off-gop-roger-stone-vote-protectors/ This is how much Trump had in hand at the end of September:  $34,776,288 
Outside groups had:	$31,072,283	
Total:  $65,848,571 On another note, the Trump campaign had purchased millions worth of TV ads in several states for mid October but then cancelled them. The campaign said the money was just being spent in other more competitive states. Many have criticized him for running the campaign on the cheap but it seems like he will cross the $500M mark afterall.
Clearly the resolution web site is a joke with data fluctuating seemingly randomly in all directions. Which unfortunately makes forecasting the question a joke, too.
I have to go with  SuperForecasting "Almost Certain" to happen $250 - $500B inclusive option.

Has anyone else noticed that the figures being shown on opensecrets.org have been jumping wildly in the last few days? Can we really trust them? https://www.opensecrets.org/pres16/ Shouldn't we be using the FEC's figures? http://www.fec.gov/press/bkgnd/pres_cf/pres_cf_Even.shtml
I wonder what will happen with this question's resolution if there is another typo on the opensecrets website on Nov 1st.

@Raahul_Kumar @Rene The total spent figure on Opensecret is $367,405,384. (down from the 519million yesterday ...)
Edit: I forgot to update my forcast ^^'

Is there something wrong with the data and/or website of Opensecrets.org? Right now, it states that 'total raised' is $218 million, and that equals the total amount in 'sources of funds'. It is also in line with the previous numbers. If I recall correctly, at the end of August they had raised approxomately $180 million and spent $143 million. However, at this moment 'total spent' is at $519 million, and outside groups have minus $300 million 'cash on hand'. That's not possible, right? The numbers have been shifting enormously in the last few days (from the moment the site-redesign went live). On October 21th, 'total spent' was at $298 million, today: $519 million. EDIT: Numbers on the site have been updated. 'Total spent' is now $367,405,384, and they have $65,854,371 'cash on hand' Thanks @The_Gnome (see https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/359626 )

Trump’s campaign has spent 86 percent of what it has raised so far. That equals 662 million.
https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/politics/2016-election/campaign-finance/ $519,175,439 is total spent
https://www.opensecrets.org/pres16/candidate?id=N00023864

@nrohr
With the closing date of this question only 9 days away, the information currently on the OpenSecrets website may the the data on which this question is resolved.  See the additional information provided to one forecaster upon his/her request, copied below from http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/279514  "Are we forecasting the value listed by the website ON November 1, or the value listed once the October fillings have been made. I've been assuming the latter, but it occurs to me that the question could be asking the former.  "The response:  The question team has discussed your request and can say that it will be based on the value listed on November 1. I do not understand why this vital information wasn't provided to all forecasters through an edit to "More Information"!

Combined total spent = 	$363,241,891  (but Trump campaign data is as of 9/30 only)
Combined cash on hand =   $64,693,882                       " I think it is safe to assume that all money raised will be spent.  That makes the total $427,935,773.  
That brings us $72,064,227 short of $500m

Looks like the last update is up for the campaign's spending.  There is a slight possibility that there will be enough spending by outside groups in future updates to put total spending over 500 million by Nov 1st, but this is pretty unlikely, especially given how the race no longer looks at all close.
I am pretty sure Opensecret changed its metodology  	 Total spend $298,553,400 (and this number seems to be without the money spent in september)
With all the CNN coverage he's gotten, who has to spend money.
According to https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/politics/2016-election/campaign-finance/ Trump's campaign has raised $403.1mm and spent $286.2mm

This is confusing. Open Secrets redesigned its site. There is no more "Total Spent" or "Combined" for spending to support Trump. No more dates. The amount of outside spending in support of Trump  jumped from $27.8 million to $84.6 million. That would be an increase of $56.8 million since September 21. Is this possible?  https://www.opensecrets.org/pres16/candidate?id=N00023864
I had not had a chance to update these since the end of August.  These are the latest numbers from Open Secrets https://www.opensecrets.org/pres16/candidate.php?id=N00023864

With the NRA reporting record spending on the Trump campaign, as well as dark money still coming in.  Trump campaign themselves using costly direct mailing campaigns, as well as the  contentious nature of the campaign itself I have made my decision.

http://www.wsj.com/articles/trump-tv-ads-proving-to-be-more-costly-1476318912 " . . .  The Democratic nominee paid a net $27,000 for 96 spots in a one-week period, while her Republican rival was charged the same amount for 83 spots. . . . a review of dozens of FCC filings revealed a pattern of the Trump campaign paying initially higher rates in battleground states than the Clinton campaign because of its tendency to book closer to air dates.
. . . 
"Given the fluidity of TV ad pricing, the Trump campaign sometimes will receive rebates from the stations. Other times, the Clinton campaign, which reserved $80 million in fall airtime in mid-August, will choose to pay more later to ensure their ads air in competitive markets. Larger stations tend to send rebates before the ads air, but smaller stations—such as WBBH—often settle their books after the fact, sometimes as late as after Election Day.
. . . 
"The Trump campaign said late last month it planned to spend $100 million on TV ads in the final weeks of the election. But it so far has booked about half that, with less than four weeks until Election Day. " . . . [Clinton's] super PAC . . .  has close to $40 million in airtime booked in the final weeks before the election. Mr. Trump’s super PACs have booked a fraction of that. "Since Mr. Trump’s TV ads have lagged so far behind Mrs. Clinton’s, some booking experts said, she has greater flexibility in choosing which ads she wants to pay a higher rate to have clear, and which she can allow to be bumped to less desirable times. "Mr. Trump and his allied super PACs spent $78 million on TV ads through September, according to data from the ad tracking firm Kantar Media/CMAG. Mrs. Clinton and her allied groups spent $325 million.
~~~~~~~
https://www.thetrace.org/2016/10/nra-breaks-campaign-spending-record/ "The National Rifle Association has spent more money trying to elect Donald Trump president and maintain Republican control of Congress than it has on any other election in history.  As of Tuesday, the NRA had poured $36.3 million into the 2016 election, breaking its own record of $31.7 million from just two years before, according to data compiled by the Center for Responsive Politics. Almost all of that money is devoted to independent expenditures, a bucket term for fliers, postcards, and television advertisements supporting or opposing candidates in federal elections, but not given directly to a campaign.
. . . 
"The increased allocations come mostly on the presidential race. Through October 11, the NRA had spent $12 million attacking Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton and $9.6 million backing Trump. That’s far more than the $13.6 million the group spent on the entire 2012 presidential race.
. . . 
"In down-ballot races, the group has spent $4.5 million on the North Carolina Senate race, about 90 percent of that attacking Democrat Deborah Ross, who is in a tight contest with incumbent Republican Richard Burr. The group has spent more than $2 million on Ohio’s Senate race, and between $1.5 million and $2 million on contested races in Nevada, Florida, Missouri, and Indiana. . . . In Wisconsin, it has spent less than $300,000 to back Senator Ron Johnson, a Republican, who pollsters expect to lose to former Senator Russ Feingold. The NRA has spent nothing to support Kelly Ayotte, a Republican senator from New Hampshire, who has faced millions of dollars in negative ads hitting her for opposing the so-called Manchin-Toomey universal background check bill in 2013, along with other gun safety votes. The NRA has also stayed out of the Pennsylvania Senate race, where Republican Pat Toomey, coauthor of that background check bill, is receiving help from gun safety groups in his tough reelection fight. Similarly, the NRA has steered clear of Illinois, where Republican Senator Mark Kirk, who has often voted with Democrats on guns, appears headed for defeat against Representative Tammy Duckworth, who also backs stronger gun laws.
~~~~~~~
http://elections.ap.org/content/ad-spending Trump reported to have spent $30m as of 10/8, which means he's spent $6.4m in the last week.  With 11 days to go that could mean $10m more.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  So, Trump's costs are up because he's making last minute ad buys, but he's still not spending very much.  Meanwhile, the NRA is spending record amounts on his behalf.

As per Gnome's comment these are the most probable buckets.
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/347992

@Raahul_Kumar  Seeing  he plan to spend 140$ million in the final 6 weeks , I doubt that Trump will spend more than 300 million in total.
So the question is how much will he spend in the last 18 days that will not be accounted for.
I use the data from 2012 as a proxy http://elections.nytimes.com/2012/campaign-finance
Between 7% and 10%  in November and between 24% and 25% in October (at least 1/3 of it will be after the 19th of October).
=> 7% +24%/3=15% and 10%+25%/3=18.3%
With those number I am between 245million and 255 million. (The range is a lot closer than I was expecting) I am discounting this a bit as the recent event will probably hurt Trump ability to raise money. http://www.politico.com/story/2016/10/rnc-halts-all-victory-project-work-for-trump-229363

Donald Trump will spend $100 million on TV ads and $40 million on digital advertising in the final six weeks of the campaign and is expanding the scope of its advertising to include three states it now deems competitive, CBS News has learned
http://www.cbsnews.com/news/donald-trump-ups-ad-spending-to-140m-expands-into-3-more-states/ Taking in account his spending to date: 127.2 million
http://www.bloomberg.com/politics/graphics/2016-presidential-campaign-fundraising/ 267.2 million is the likely total.

There certainly won't be a big rush of right wing big money donors for Trump now (though big money left wing donors have had no problem keeping the Clintons in private jets and Four Seasons' for the past 20 years!)
Dipping below $250 million following Trump's troubles.

http://elections.ap.org/content/trump-once-data-skeptic-spending-millions-data "The Trump analytics team has become increasingly confident in its work, saying the campaign has raised more than $150 million online
~~~~~~~
http://elections.ap.org/content/ad-spending "Total money spent on campaign ads, as of last Saturday: Clinton   $199.3M
Trump     $23.6M
~~~~~~
COMMENT:  The AP data seems to not include the spending by any outside groups.

I have just read a couple of reports that the Trump campaign is planning to spend $100-140m in the final stretch.  The ability to do that will rest on his fund-raising because he had only about $62m cash on hand as of 9/21.
Well, we're not going to get the number for the campaign's spending in September until the FEC filing date: October 20. It's guesswork in the meantime.
Now think this is more like a 50-50 chance. Slightly tipping it in the positive direction in case the surge expected in October gets captured by Nov 1.

With approximately $116M spent and $50M on hand at the end of August, the Trump campaign was on track to spend close to $200M on its own by now. The evidence? Trump TV ads started appearing in earnest in MN-- not a hotly contested state of late-- just before the first debate, signalling a general increase in spending.  Outside groups had spent another $28M by the third week of September. Assuming that fundraising hasn't come to a skidding stop, $250M is achievable. Much more than that, however, is unlikely.

http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/campaign-finance-clinton-trump-bush-rubio_us_57f2c63be4b0d0e1a9a9360c "Billionaire Donald Trump’s presidential bid features an unprecedented mixing of a candidate’s corporate and campaign resources. The campaign pays Trump companies for rent, staff, air travel, event space, catering and more. And the campaign doesn’t seem concerned with the size of those bills.  "As HuffPost’s S.V. Dáte reported, the campaign’s spending on Trump’s own properties increased as soon as outside donor contributions began to make up the majority of the campaign’s receipts. "Trump nearly quintupled the monthly rent that his campaign paid for its headquarters at Trump Tower ― from $35,458 in March, when he was self-funding his campaign, to $169,758 in July, when he was raising funds from others ― according to a HuffPost review of FEC filings. The rent jumped even though he was paying fewer staff in July than he did in March. "The candidate also made extravagant expenditures when cheaper alternatives were easily available. These included the use of his opulent Mar-a-Lago Club for victory parties and press conferences and the use of his own 757 jet, instead of a much smaller, cheaper plane that could have still ferry his small staff.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  Here's what I think is important in this article: ". . .   the campaign’s spending on Trump’s own properties increased as soon as outside donor contributions began to make up the majority of the campaign’s receipts. Trump nearly quintupled the monthly rent that his campaign paid . . . ".  This suggests to me that reported campaign expenditures are going to soar, putting the cost into the next higher bin.

Total Raised to Date . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . $182.1M as of Sep 21.
http://www.bloomberg.com/politics/graphics/2016-presidential-campaign-fundraising/ $250 million is a very hard target to hit. It is clear that Trump has been massively outspent by HC.

It's going to be close. Trump's campaign spent only $30 million in August. Will it spend more in September? We should get spending through October 19 by the time this question closes. Plus some spending by outside groups. I'm going to guess $75 million from the Trump campaign plus outside groups. That would be under $250 million. I will stick with that until I see the September number.
Between 9/12 and 9/21 OpenSecrets reported Outside Sources raised approx 5 million and spent approx. 3 million.
Taking a milder position. Dropping from 85% to 72%.
Given the predictable October spike in spending, am now leaning towards the consensus view that the second bucket is the most likely one. Raising the second bucket from 45% to 85%.

Corrected to take into account the filling on October 27, 2016. (For the period October 1 - 19, 2016) 
It is going to be very close. http://www.fec.gov/info/report_dates_2016.shtml#general @Anneinak seeing your last comment, I thought it might interested you.(I am not sure how fast opensecrets update its website.)
adjusting forecast since October expenditures will not be included.

Need to check on October 1 to see how long it takes OpenSecrets to post the September number for Campaign Committee spending. But Oct 1 is a Saturday. Presumably, nothing will be posted until Oct 3. November 1, a Tuesday, will be a different situation.

Initial forecast at 55%.  Since Trump has spent only about 140 Million so far, he needs to spend an additional 110 Million to get to the second lowest bucket. It is unlikely that Trump will splurge $100 Million in September alone. The real splurge typically happens in October, but since this question will probably capture the spend for the first couple of weeks of October (update scheduled for around Oct 20), it is quite possible to break above $250 Million.
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/330162

Trump has raised $205,860,765, yet only spent $143,365,882 in total. It seems less and less likely he could raise $300 million or spend 80% of it.
https://www.opensecrets.org/pres16/candidate.php?id=N00023864 The lower two buckets are where the odds should be distributed and lowest one needs to be favored.

So if i get it right Donald trump need to spend pretty much 100 million in September to be in the 250 million-500 million bracket. As the October data will not be included ( https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/279514).
Trump's campaign is reported to be on track as the least expensive presidential campaign in recent history.

"As of 1 November 2016" - There should only be one more update to the resolution source, some time around Oct. 20.  As a result the heavy spend in the last two weeks of the campaign may not be included in the final numbers for this Q.
  Current spend total of $139,979,000 is an increase of approx 43,000,000 (29 from committee and 14 from outside) since Aug. 22nd. Over the past two months outside spend has increased from approx 3,000,000 to 14,000,000 per month.  
  To date Trump has raised 201m and spent 140m, with about 64m raised in the past month from all sources.  Donations have incresed, but the required increase in spend over the next month to $110,000,000 might be too much.
Seems  unlikely that Trump's spend will cross the $250,000,000 mark, although further large increases in outside money may make a difference.
9/12 Open Secrets post shows approx 12m additional "outside" spend since 8/22.

Outside groups continue to spend relatively little on Trump.  The campaign reportedly raised 90 million in August with the RNC, but when the breakdown between Trump and the party is released a significant portion is likely to go to the party as has been the case in previous months.  Nonetheless he seems to be on track to surpass 250 million raised by the end of September.  Because this question asks for the amount that will be reported on November 1st, there are only two more months of campaign totals to be reported, so Trump would have to see a massive spike in fundraising to reach 500 million.

OpenSecrets shows $137 million to date. Lower buckets are now much more likely.
https://www.opensecrets.org/pres16/candidate.php?id=N00023864
His rate of spending should be higher in August, September, October than it was in July.

"As of Nov. 1" OpenSecrets data may only reflect spend through Sept. 30, if the monthly updates continue.  Currently spend is reported as 97 million through July 31, with committe spend at only 18 million for July.  Assuming that spend was not drastically increased during August, a low forecast seems best option.

http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2016-election/hillary-clinton-allies-outpace-team-trump-fundraising-n635346
 Donald Trump: Raised in July: $36.6 million Raised in June: $26.7 million Spent in July: $18.5 million Cash on Hand: $38.4 million

both candidates in 2012 spend 2.1 times their june funds. this trent  looks consistent. 2.1 times 300 mil ( trump june fund ) is 600. constancy is more lilely broken upwards by rare event than downwards ( its already low )

Lets look at 2012 for patterns -  http://elections.nytimes.com/2012/campaign-finance Romney + RNC spent -
254 - Through June
71 -  July
114 - Aug
107 - Sept
188 - Oct 2016 - http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2016/us/elections/election-2016-campaign-money-race.html
Clinton through june - 240 (open secrets - 290 as of last filing)
Trump through June - 65 (open secrets - 76) So the Trump campaign has been surprising, while Clinton is following the usual trend.  Will Republican donors back Trump?   Lets assume a median of 300 mil more and a sd of 150 mil.  So Normal(380, 150) 19% < 250
60% 250 - 500
21% > 500  That's a good prior.  Adjusting for intuition.

84 days from today. 3 months. At the highest rate of fundraising Donald has achieved: “Donald Trump also had his best fundraising month of the campaign, raising $80 million"
http://www.politico.com/story/2016/08/trump-fundraising-sets-off-clinton-camp-alarms-226779 240 million in 3 months + $100 million in bank implies 250-500 million is his likely end goal. The lowest bucket is unlikely, and substantially less than Romney managed, which is odd.
Morning news reports Trump is articulating mainstream GOP economic positions.

Some of the donors are holding back. Koch brothers are going after the senate and house races. Even Meg Whitman is going to raise money for Hillary! Still think there are enough party loyalists who will give money to the Trump campaign.

Short term forecast; based on possibility Trump may leave race.
http://www.newsmax.com/Headline/trump-drop-out-options/2016/08/03/id/741897/
Thanks @lindsey for the clarification.  On August 2, the date of reports are June 30 and July 21.  Which means we could be looking at a lag of 2 to 3 weeks on Nov 1.

There were reports in the media yesterday that David Koch had resisted attempts to set up a meeting with Trump while they were both in Colorado this week.  It's post Convention and the Koch brothers are not coming around, they have been quoted in the press saying that Hillary Clinton would make a better president than Trump.  (Along with the Americans for Prosperity PAC, they spend close to $40 million in the 2012 election http://www.motherjones.com/politics/2012/11/charts-map-koch-brothers-2012-spending) This is important, not only in terms of the large amounts of cash they can inject into a campaign, but also in terms of their influence among the top donors in the GOP.   Here are the most recent Open Secrets numbers for Trump: Trump's campaign committee raised $88,997,986 
Outside groups supporting Trump raised $9,744,105. 
Together they have spent $76,407,397 
More data here:  http://www.opensecrets.org/pres16/candidate.php?id=N00023864 Outside groups have already spent a staggering $81,205,596 AGAINST Trump and $61,018,152 IN SUPPORT of his candidacy.   Compare that to Hillary:  Total spent by outside groups AGAINST Hillary is $11,536,026 and the total spent in her favor is $17,607,638!   Last, this is the list of the top campaign donors.  Will be worth it taking a look at how they stand in support of Trump so far: https://www.opensecrets.org/orgs/list.php
Well currently Trump spent 1/4 of what Hillary Clinton did so if she spend around 1 billion, he would be around 250 million.

Through June 30 (the most recent data available at OpenSecrets.org), $76.5M had been spent by and on behalf of the Trump campaign.  Though spending and travel appear largely limited to battleground states, Mr. Trump & Co. could easily have crossed the $100M mark going in to Cleveland. The failure of the RNC to produce a significant poll bump may finally force deep pocketed donors and outside groups to commit funds. Add the "Russia" flap, and their best bet at getting control of the message, and influencing down-ticket outcomes, may be to end-run the messenger with on-script media. This raises the chances that spending will cross the $250M mark, and even the $500M mark. But $750M seems out of reach at this late date and with Mr. Trump's high negatives. High-profile donors (e.g., Koch) are maintaining tellingly low profiles.

"Trump had his strongest fundraising month of the election in June.  He raised $26.7 million directly into his campaign." "Donations of $200 or less accounted for nearly half the money raised.  Small donors "could prove crucial to Trump as he taps them repeatedly for contributions before they hit the $2,700 cap on what each can donate" "His June fundraising total also includes more than $3.8 million from the candidate himself. The Republican spent a scant $7.8 million last month, a paltry sum for a major party nominee. But he started July with $20.2 million in available cash, his strongest cash position of the election." http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2016/07/20/hillary-clinton-donald-trump-june-fundraising-president-pacs/87341740/

As of this prediction opensecrets is reporting Trump & outside groups at approx $100k raised and $75k spent, while Hillary is at approx $375k and $300k.  I am assuming that Hillary will end up near what Romney and Obama did in 2012.  Trump remains far behind, and if Clinton and Trump continue to fundraise and spend proportional to how they have thus far (roughly triple their current amounts) Trump will only end up around $300k.  Given the amount of money in US politics I still expect Trump to beat that figure, but his continued lack of money from outside groups makes me wonder a bit.

Media just got a copy of Drumpf's speech for the RNC Convention closing tonight. From what it sounds like, the party if being gutted. It's Drumpf's party now.    I am reducing my forecast because, from what it seems, the party will not come out as unified as expected (see Ted Cruz's speech last night, Kasich's revolt) and traditional, powerful donors have not been energized enough to jump in and support Drumpf the way he needs to match Hillary's numbers.   This article is one example:   Powerful Republican family holding out against nominee
http://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/288590-powerful-republican-family-holding-out-against-nominee "Betsy DeVos is attending this year's convention as a Michigan delegate supporting John Kasich, but she concedes her family has effectively given up on presidential politics this year unless Drumpf dramatically changes his tune."  Clearly, that is not going to happen.   Having worked in major capital campaigns for years, tells me that, as with other things, Drumpf has not put together the infrastructure necessary to raise the money the campaign is expected to raise and may not have the time he needs to do so.   Of course, now that the party will be behind him, a lot is going to improve and that team is one well-oiled machine if there ever was one.  We will have to see how willing Drumpf is to working with them and taking their cue.  He may just decide to continue the same strategies he has used until now.

@lindsey:  Thank you for sharing the email response.

Wanted to share a response I received from GJOpen on this question:

My email: For the question "As of 1 November 2016, how much money will the Center for Responsive Politics report that Donald Trump..." Are we forecasting the value listed by the website ON November 1, or the value listed once the October fillings have been made. I've been assuming the latter, but it occurs to me that the question could be asking the former.
Thanks so much!
Lindsey The response: Sorry for the delay in responding to your clarification request. The question team has discussed your request and can say that it will be based on the value listed on November 1. Forecast: My previous forecasts assumed the question would not be resolved until the October 2016 filing for the campaign committee was reported. New numbers assume campaign spending up to and including September, but not October. @dada @Raahul_Kumar

It's July already. Realistically, most of the spending that is yet to occur will happen in the week leading up to both conventions-- priming the pump for and against each nominee-- and the month preceding the election. Mr. Trump's surprising June fundraising, and conversion of his campaign self-loans to a donation (http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2016/2016/07/06/donald-trump-and-rnc-raise-51-million-june/86757706/), have all but erased the likelihood of a rice-and-beans budget, but the fundraising calendar is still working against him.

Looking at the past two presidential elections (Mccain and Romney), both candidates thru May of election year had spent 80m and 106m, respectively. Trump as of end of May is currently at 66m. Mccain and Romney in total spent 240m and 483m, respectively. Looking at Mccain's spending patterns, relative to Romneys, Mccain didn't double his cumulative May spending pattern till the final quarter of the race, while Romney doubled his cumulative May spending by August. Given trump is already behind both of these prior candidates, it would appear likely that he, at current, underspends both of them.

Trump is not very popular among the establishment, which won't draw many funds from large political donors.

As of Brexit weekend, Mr. Trump's campaign remains a singularly self-centered enterprise. The fact that roughly ten percent of all campaign spending runs through Trump entities will not be lost on donors. Neither will his polling numbers in June, which were lackluster at best. A bigger bang for the deep-pocketed buck may be had further down the ticket, making a skewed fundraising picture all the more likely. Holding the House and state legislatures (at least) will become the primary orientation of top Republican officials, as their ability to influence the presumptive nominee is fully acknowledged. Meanwhile, as money fails to come in, the presidential campaign will take on a different, less costly, media aspect. This will not harm the candidate, however. He has already received so much free publicity that his name recognition is total. Neither does he need to spend money outlining policy; he makes that up on the spot... in 140-character cost-free bursts. And then there's the convention. Despite themselves-- and I include myself here-- millions of voters will tune in just for the Dionysian excess. (A gold balloon drop?) Debates, likewise, come at low (no) cost to the candidate, and will certainly have monstrous audiences.  Having come this far while spending so little on conventional campaigning, I can't see a compelling reason for Mr. Trump to change strategies now. Leave advocacy ads to the outside groups; they'll pick up the tab eventually.
He'll lack large donors but get broad-based popular (low dollar) support. Factoring in different, non-standard approach to electoral politics.

From what I've learned, just the fact that this is a GJP question tells me something is up. It should be a no brainer given past campaigns expenses, right? But Trump has hinted he will self-fund his campaign. Maybe this question takes root on that. But most sources say he couldn't afford it even if he wanted. Or, if he could afford it, would he even want to? It's not as if he were Bloomberg (worth $40B). There were reports last week that Trump was given a list of 30 top GOP donors to call and only called 3 before quitting (NY Post). Then he appeared along Reince Preibus in both New York City and Texas in successful fundraising events.  So this question might be about:  1) Trump's willingness to go along with the status quo or his actual ability to raise campaign funds (a known dealbreaker for any candidate at any level). 
2) Concerns that the RNC isn't doing enough to help Trump financially. The NYT said this week that the RNC recently formed TWO joint fundrasing committees and that they have been instructing their largest donors on "how they can minimize or zero out the amount of their cash going to Trump."  Some pro-Trump Super PACs, according to the NYT, have told wealthy Republicans that if they want to help Trump, giving to the RNC isn't enough.   Can Trump and the RNC get it together to raise enough money or is it already looking challenging? Note that a chunk of campaign money comes from what the candidate himself raises, then the party, then how much Super Pacs invest. Good illustration here: http://elections.nytimes.com/2012/campaign-finance ) Interestingly, and as reported also by the NY Times this week, when Trump toyed around with an independent run in 2000, he said: "It's very possible that I could be the first presidential candidate to run and make money on it."  He could end up turning a profit if he repaid himself for the campaign loans!    Same NYT article said that:  "...the extent to which Mr. Trump was utilizing his own businesses for his run was unprecedented and that because of his unique financial circumstances, he was wading into territory that went beyond the FEC's guidance." Here is Trump's full FEC filing http://docquery.fec.gov/pdf/514/201606209018595514/201606209018595514.pdf  But all that seems to me as more of a general strategy for the primary campaign which he ran so successfully. 
I would think that Trump will just fall in line with the RNC and the party's traditional fundraising efforts and campaigning. You can already see signs of that this week. The day after Lewandowski gets fired, Trump gives a speech in a completely different tone, "savaging" Hillary. It has RNC strategies stamps all over.  Trump himself, in addressing the firing of Lewandowski said that the campaign is now moving on a different direction. Lewandowski was the "genius" behind "let Trump be Trump" which got the candidate where he is now. As the nominee, Trump's strategy (in which he raised so little and spent so little in comparison) is not going to work as well as it did in the primary. The campaign is now taking a different direction and he will need as much money as he can raise. Releasing Lewandowski is a clear a signal of a switch in strategy and the GOP taking over as there ever will be.  This is from the 2012 race and can give us an idea of where money comes from: http://elections.nytimes.com/2012/campaign-finance
Republican estab and donors don't want him elected.

I am basing my predictions off the last election cycle's spending records, in which Mitt Romney who was in June hugely (to the tune of several hundred million dollars) ahead of where the Donald is right now.  Raising money has been much easier since Citizens United, but Trump is very unpopular with the donor class of the Republican party, with many forgoing donating to him, instead focusing on senate races etc. Even if he were to keep up with previous fundraising levels seen last election, he would at this point be hard pressed to break the 1 billion dollar mark.

I'm not sure from the wording of the question if RNC spending on behalf of Trump will count towards the total. Regardless, the RNC and outside groups each spent around $400 million on behalf of Romney in 2012 (according to opensecrets.org).  Trump may not get quite as much support from outside groups--the Koch brothers have already stated that they do not intend to spend money in support of Trump--but using 2012 as a guide it still seems likely that spending for Trump will easily exceed $500 million, and over $1 billion is very possible.

Trump is already at 64mm and the general election is just getting under way. And while Trump doesn't seem to be fundraising much right now, he seems to be understanding what's going on (has been doing a LOT more fundraisers recently).  The Super PACs have also been doing a lot of work and the RNC is helping with fundraising.

The Trump campaign may not be very successful at raising money at the moment, but outside groups will be, even if they don't actually spend much of it on the candidate himself. Call it a scam within a scam.
A prime example is Scott B  Mackenzie,chairman of Patriots for Trump PAC, who should have his own Wikipedia article since he has been doing this since Reagan.

Most of the money in 2012 was spent in the last few months of the election, but Trump would have to spend (and raise!) at the same level as Obama did in June-October 2012 just to reach $750 million.  From what I've read, he comes nowhere close to the level of organization or connections Romney and Obama had - and hasn't even been asking major donors to contribute. http://elections.nytimes.com/2012/campaign-finance  Good source for 2012 comparison.
